hints.content: Start by understanding the problem statement clearly. You need to find the shortest distance between two words in a list. Make sure you know how to measure distance in terms of indices.
Consider how you would iterate through the list of words. You might want to keep track of the last seen indices of the two words you are comparing.
Think about how to handle cases where the two words are the same. If the words are identical, you need to ensure you are calculating the distance between different occurrences.
When you find one of the words, store its index. You can then check if the other word has been seen before to calculate the distance.
Remember that the distance is defined as the absolute difference between the indices of the two words. Use `abs(index1 - index2)` to calculate this.
Consider edge cases, such as when the list contains only one of the words or when both words are not present at all. How will you handle these scenarios?
As you iterate through the list, keep a variable to track the minimum distance found so far. Update this variable whenever you find a shorter distance.
If you encounter the same word multiple times, ensure that you are not using the same index for both occurrences when calculating distance.
Think about how to efficiently manage the indices of the two words. You might want to use two separate variables to keep track of their last seen positions.
Finally, ensure that you return the minimum distance found after completing the iteration through the list. If no valid distance was found, consider what you should return.

questionNotes: The input is a list of words, and you need to find the shortest distance between two specific words.
The words can be the same, so handle that case carefully by checking different occurrences.
You must return the minimum distance as an integer.
If either word is not present in the list, you should define the behavior (e.g., return -1 or some error value).
